goals: Describe how a value model can support cyber decision making
Identify relevant metrics and best practices that can be used to secure cyber systems
Discuss how and when metrics and best practices can differ by organization
outcomes: Apply and Analyze: Create measures and value functions for cyber metrics decision making
Remember and Understand: List metrics and best practices that are appropriate for cybersecurity for individuals
Evaluate and Synthesize: Evaluate personal security and identify opportunities for improvement

units.name:
Natalie Scala, Towson University

Adapted from:
An Inventory of and Model for Cybersecurity Values: Metrics and Best Practices - Scala and Goethals. (2017)
A Value Model for Implementing Cyber Metrics and Best Practices - Scala et al. (2017)

units.text: Summary:

Each individual, company, or organization has unique values for cybersecurity. These values are what we care about when protecting ourselves and our systems from hackers and malicious actors. Value modeling can help us identify our values and needs in order to mitigate risk and support following best practices that help to keep our systems and devices secure.
Description:

Every individual, company, or organization wants secure cyber systems. Our security should reflect what we value and include levels of protection and monitoring appropriate for the type and amount of data and assets that we are concerned about. As a result, each individual, company, or organization may value different things. For example, a large university may care about protecting student data in PeopleSoft, but a small legal firm may care about preventing phishing. An individual may be concerned about the security of his or her files stored on a third party cloud, such as iCloud or Amazon Cloud Drive. Each organization is unique, based on its characteristics and demographics, such as size of firm, history of attacks and/or breaches, industry sector, size of cybersecurity budget, network sophistication, and adversarial threat.

Cyber attacks and breaches can and do happen to anyone. The map below is adapted from Farahani, Scala, Goethals, and Tagert (2016) and shows prominent businesses in Maryland, USA that were breached over a two year window. This is just one state in the United States of America, and the reported breached organizations vary by size and economic sector.

units.text: How Can We Protect Our Networks?

How can we protect our data and secure our networks? We can implement metrics and best practices to support strong operating procedures and reliable monitoring of our systems.  The choices of metrics and best practices are vast.  The National Security Agency’s (NSA) Science of Security initiative has indexed 110 papers related to metrics and best practices as of October 2016 (SoS, 2016); the Information Assurance Directorate (IAD) of NSA suggests ten top practices (NSA IAD, 2013); and various academic journals such as Viduto, Maple, Huang, and López-Peréz (2012) and Santos, Haimes, and Lian (2007) suggest a list of metrics and best practices.  In fact, Viduto, et al. (2012) suggest twenty-four  metrics for cybersecurity, including system administration, maintaining use of passwords, firewalls, patching, and separation of duties, and Santos, at al. (2007) identify four categories of metrics: cybersecurity cost, network vulnerability, equipment downtime, and production delay.

We cannot implement everything!  No organization has enough budget, some may not have enough sophistication, time is an issue, and some metrics and best practices may not be relevant for the system.  Regardless, we need adaptive responses to the adversaries, hackers, and malicious actors.

How do we choose which metrics and best practices to implement?  Cyber maturity plays a role.  For example, large universities that already have some best practices in place are going to choose different metrics to add to their networks vs. small businesses or casual individuals who have little or no experience in cybersecurity.  So, to help us figure out what we care about and what is appropriate for our systems, we can use a value model.  This approach will help us mitigate risk by addressing core needs to create secure systems.
Answer the following questions:

units.prompt: The same cyber metrics and best practices should be implemented at every organization.
What we value or care about for cybersecurity may change over time.
How many metrics and best practices has Science of Security indexed?

units.text: Value focused thinking (VFT) is a decision analysis method where the decision maker brainstorms everything he or she cares about in a decision process (Keeney, 2008).  The goal is to identify values or needs that are both conscious and unconscious, without being biased by constraints, alternatives, or cost.  What we care about is then arranged into a hierarchy, with the values, or cares, referred to as measures.  A hierarchy will show relationships and if any value is dependent on or a subset of another measure.  Hierarchies and the VFT process allow us to organize our thoughts and clearly identify what is important in the decision process.  Further details on VFT and the related multiple objective decision analysis process can be found in Keeney (1992; 2008), Parnell (2007), Keeney & Raiffa (1976), and Kirkwood (1997).

We can use VFT to identify what we value in a secure cyber system in order to create a hierarchy of measures.  Each measure then needs a value function, which identifies the best, worst, and intermediate cases of each measure.  The best case receives a score of 100; the worst case gets a score of 0; and intermediate cases receive scores in between, corresponding to the amount of value each case provides.

Because each organization, industry, or individual is unique, the hierarchy of measures may be different corresponding to what is valued.  To build the hierarchy, we talk to the decision makers and subject matter experts at the organization or company in order to understand what they care about when securing their cyber systems.  We take notes during the conversation and then create the hierarchy based on what we learned.

Simple Solutions is a company that specializes in supply chain logistics and services a number of clients with their shipping and transportation needs. The IT Department at Simple Solutions wants to secure the company’s network and created a value hierarchy, which is shown below. Securing the cyber systems is the overall goal, and there are six main measures: data integrity, end-to-end security, cloud based services, policies, intrusion and threat detection, and vulnerability mitigation. Intrusion and threat detection has multiple components, so we break it down into two sub-measures: monitoring and reaction.

A value function is then created for each measure, but it is created for each sub-measure if the measure is broken down. We call the measures that have value functions lowest level measures, as there nothing underneath them on the hierarchy. In this example, we create value functions for data integrity, end-to-end security, cloud based services, policies, and vulnerability mitigation, but not intrusion and threat detection, as it has two sub-measures. Instead we create value functions for monitoring and reaction, for a total of seven functions relating to seven lowest level measures.

To create value functions, we once again interview decision makers and subject matter experts and ask them what they desire for each measure. What is the best case? What is the worst case? What are intermediate cases that are important, and how good are those cases? We do this for every lowest level measure. As an example, the value function for data integrity for Simple Solutions is shown below:

cells.first: Existence of security and access permissions, existence of transaction or version logs, having and using audit process
Existence of security and access permissions, existence of transaction or version logs
Existence of security and access permissions, having and using audit process
Existence of transaction or version logs, having and using audit process
Existence of security and access permissions
Existence of transaction or version logs

units.text: Therefore, the best case for data integrity is a metric or best practice that can support existence of both security and access permissions and transaction or version logs and has or uses an audit process. Those metrics or best practices would score 100 points. An example of an intermediate case is a metric or best practice that supports the existence of only transaction and version logs; that metric or best practice would receive only 30 points.

Because our overall goal is to identify which metrics and best practices we should implement to support secure cyber systems, we then evaluate our alternatives, in this case our list of metrics and best practices, against the value functions to see how they perform for every lowest level measure. For example, we can use the Information Assurance top 10 practices and evaluate each of them against every lowest level measure. In this case, for data integrity, we have application whitelisting receiving a score of 70, as whitelisting supports security and access permissions (50 points) and audit access (20 points). Similarly, control administrative privileges receives a score of 100 for data integrity, as it supports everything: security and access permissions (50 points), audit access (20 points), and existence of transaction and version logs (30 points).

For Simple Solutions, data integrity has a weight of 0.156. Then for application whitelisting, we take 70 * 0.156 for data integrity and add it to the other six measures. Doing so gives us the final list of metrics and best practices scores, organized from highest to lowest:

cells.first: Use web domain name system reputation
Implement host intrusion prevention system (HIPS) rules

units.text: How does this help?

Once we have the metrics and best practices arranged in rank order based on value, we can then make a recommendation regarding what to implement. In this example, control administrative privileges is #1 and best supports what Simple Solutions cares about in securing their cyber systems. Limit workstation-to-workstation communication is in second place, followed by take advantage of software improvements, and so on. A company can then implement these metrics and best practices in order from highest rank to lowest rank until they run out of budget, time, or other resources. If they implement all of them, they can then use the model to create a new list of additional metrics. They could also evaluate another list of metrics and best practices before implementing this list, to see if other ones score higher, which would mean more impact on value. Finally, if the values of the company or organization change, the hierarchy and value functions can be updated, with the model then used to suggest the preferred metrics and best practices to support secure cyber systems under the new conditions.

Overall the model provides a methodology to incorporate value into decision making for securing cyber systems.  This approach enables companies, organizations, and individuals to identify metrics and best practices that are most aligned and appropriate for their systems.
Answer the following questions:

units.prompt: Which of the following is not a measure on a value hierarchy for Simple Solutions?
The best case scenario in a value function receives a score of 0.
How many value functions are needed for Simple Solutions?
'Take advantage of software improvements' was the highest scoring metric for Simple Solutions.

units.text: Consider your personal cybersecurity, including hardware and data.  Examples of hardware include your mobile phone, laptop, tablet, video game console (Xbox), streaming video player (Roku), intelligent personal assistant (Alexa), and other devices in the Internet of Things.  Examples of data include your photos, class term papers, videos, profile information, and other personal files.

Identify three measures or values that are important to you in securing your personal cybersecurity. What characteristics of your personal cyber systems (devices) are needed in order to secure your personal data?

Then for each measure or value, create a value function.  Identify the best case and worst case for each measure.  Also identify intermediate cases.  What are the corresponding values, on a scale from 0-100, for each case?
Think about how these measures or values can affect online behavior.  Now that you are aware of what you care about, will you make any changes to how you approach your personal cybersecurity?
Security Checklist
Consider the following list of metrics, which are adapted from Farahani, et al. (2016) and the IAD top 10 list (NSA IAD, 2013).

cells.second: Baiting adversaries who use social media to collect information or launch attacks
Identifying characters in a URL that can contain sensitive or personal information
Measure system vulnerability and predict how likely system will be compromised
Identify locations of potential vulnerabilities in system
Rate of speed before a patch to fix a vulnerability is released and installed
Using administrator privileges only when truly necessary and needed
Limiting connections between devices on a network in order to limit damage if a device in the system is compromised

cells.first: Use web domain name system reputation
cells.second: Screening web access requests and redirecting requests for questionable websites to a warning page
Installing patches and other trusted updates to software and apps
Using anti-virus capabilities, including real time updates that may be cloud supported

units.prompt: Which metrics and best practices on the list are appropriate for personal cybersecurity?  That is, which ones are metrics and best practices that we we should score using the value model when considering personal cybersecurity?
Are there any potential metrics and best practices for personal cybersecurity that should be added?  If so, what are they?
